results.headline: Scissors, Shaver and Salvation for a Young Barber
results.summary_short: The job of custom barber is a Colombian teenager’s ticket to a world beyond his poor family and rough past in “La Playa D.C.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Playa

results.headline: The Weight of History, Undercut by Day-Trippers
results.summary_short: “Centro Histórico,” a set of four films inspired by the Portuguese city of Guimarães, ranges from light to lyrical to troubling.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Centro Histórico

results.headline: Where a Junkyard Becomes a Playground
results.summary_short: “Broken,” a British feature from Rufus Norris, focuses on Skunk, a curious 11-year-old girl who bears a resemblance to Scout Finch in “To Kill a Mockingbird.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broken

results.headline: From Diapers to Throne
results.summary_short: The BBC documentary “Born to Royalty” uses archival images of the royal family, going back to Queen Victoria, ostensibly to tell a story about changing royal parental styles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Born to Royalty

results.headline: Death as a Youthful Mystery
results.summary_short: Gustavo Ron’s “Ways to Live Forever” is a forthright and surprisingly buoyant drama about facing death before you have really lived.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ways To Live Forever

results.headline: Snail’s Pace Can Win the Race
results.summary_short: A snail who thinks he can do great things is supercharged by ambition in “Turbo,” but there is a trail of big commercial interests in the story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turbo

results.headline: Girls Behaving Badly at a Film Festival
results.summary_short: “Les Coquillettes” follows the fictional exploits of the film director Sophie Letourneur and her two friends at the Locarno Film Festival in Switzerland.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Les Coquillettes

results.headline: Youth League Tantrums, but Not by the Kids
results.summary_short: In “Dealin’ With Idiots,” Jeff Garlin lampoons the obsessions of adults with children on a baseball team.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dealin' With Idiots

results.headline: Code-Writing Pioneers, It’s Your Turn
results.summary_short: “Computer Chess” is set in 1980 at a gathering where computer programs created by nerds face human competition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Computer Chess

results.headline: In a Town of Hunters, a Maligned Man Falls Prey to Malice
results.summary_short: Mads Mikkelsen plays a teacher suspected of being a pedophile in “The Hunt,” set in a Danish village.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunt

results.headline: Narrow Space in Society, if Any, for Anonymity
results.summary_short: “Terms and Conditions May Apply” examines the repercussions of clicking on the “Agree” button on those dense (and typically unread) online user contracts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Terms and Conditions May Apply

results.headline: Psychedelic Euphoria Wears Off in the Desert
results.summary_short: In “Crystal Fairy,” two young Americans attend a coke-and-pot-fueled party and go on a road trip with three Chilean brothers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crystal Fairy

results.headline: A New Year, and a Last Day Alive
results.summary_short: “Fruitvale Station,” based on the true story of a Bay Area black man shot by a white police officer on a subway platform, examines the subject with a steady, objective eye.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fruitvale Station

results.headline: A Simple Swap or Sale? Not Here
results.summary_short: The three tales in “Pawn Shop Chronicles” involve robbery, meth and an Elvis impersonator.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pawn Shop Chronicles

results.headline: Two Performers at Different Stages
results.summary_short: Walter Saabel and Philipp Hochmair star in “The Shine of Day,” directed by Tizza Covi and Rainer Frimmel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Shine of Day

results.headline: It’s Never Too Late for Hoop Dreams
results.summary_short: In “The Hot Flashes,” a group of plucky middle-aged Texas women form a basketball team to raise money for breast cancer prevention.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hot Flashes

results.headline: Monsters, Machines and Mind Melding in a Race for the World
results.summary_short: In “Pacific Rim,” Guillermo del Toro’s new movie, the Jaeger manned robots fight the Kaiju monsters to save the planet.

results.headline: It’s Bosnia in Appalachia
results.summary_short: A soldier bent on revenge tracks down his target in “Killing Season.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Killing Season

results.headline: Political Brutality Sets a Running Champion on His Path
results.summary_short: This Bollywood biopic trails Milkha Singh from his military training through noteworthy competitions in the 1950s at home and abroad.

results.headline: In Defense of Self-Defense
results.summary_short: “Assaulted: Civil Rights Under Fire” features Ted Nugent, gun store owners and clips from Fox News.
